text: All right, I think everything’s go for the cameras.  We’re going to start off today just by doing our daily word problems.  I’m going to pass these out real quick, and what I want you to do, if you would, is try to solve these problems.  Remember just to try to use everyday kind of logic. Don’t try to think about it too much, just try your best on these, Okay?  What I want you to do is probably just – why don’t we just stick with the second one where it says “Thursday Week Seven.”  You don’t have to do the first one right now; we’ll come back to that. Let me just read this real quick while you’re kind of working on it. It says, “Miss W’s class read for a total of 450 hours this month.  Mr. G’s class read two-thirds the number of hours read by Miss W’s class.  Miss R’s class read twice the number of hours read by Mr. G’s class.  If there were a total of 90 students in these three classrooms, what was the average number of hours read per student?” What was the average?  Remember we were doing a little bit of averaging yesterday?  So what you need to do is find the total of hours and divide that by the number of students. That will give you the average that each student read. So we have 450 hours this month that these 90 students read, right? So what is the average?  They’re asking you, what is the average amount?  Maybe they had one super student that read all 450 hours, right?  And then the 89 other students didn't read at all.  But they’re looking for the average. Go ahead.
speaker: teacher

text: The answer?

Symmetry, what is symmetry? Hold on, hold on.  Did I spell that wrong?  I did spell that wrong.  You guys.  S-Y-M-M-E-T-R-Y.  Symmetry.  My bad. And does anybody know what symmetry is?
